name: Alaska Seeds of Change
category: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska
description: This vocational program supports young people (ages 16-24) and Alaska Behavioral Health clients in building job skills and personal resilience through gardening. They offer a trauma-informed, nature-based space for healing and growth
services: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska consultation

name: Alaska Botanical Garden
category: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska
description: While not exclusively a therapeutic gardening program, the Alaska Botanical Garden offers programs like "Health and Wellness in the Garden" and "Guided Gardening" that incorporate horticultural therapy principles, focusing on mental and physical well-being through gardening activities
services: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska consultation

name: University of Alaska Fairbanks Cooperative Extension Service - Community Garden and Garden to Heal Program
category: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska
description: This program provides community members with hands-on gardening experience, including educational classes and access to expertise. It fosters community and offers opportunities for practical gardening skills
services: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska consultation

name: Alaska Master Gardener Program
category: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska
description: This program, offered through the UAF Cooperative Extension Service, trains individuals to become Master Gardeners. While not a direct therapeutic program, Master Gardeners often volunteer in community gardens and support horticultural therapy initiatives. They have associations in various communities across Alaska
services: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska consultation

name: MYHouse's Halcyon Garden
category: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska
description: This garden offers at-risk youth opportunities to build skills, grow food, and find connection through meaningful work. It's described as a place of healing and growth, with produce often used in their social enterprise cafe
services: Gen-Z-owned Therapeutic gardening programs in Alaska consultation
